awd_titl_txt: EAPSI: Examining the Long-term Health Benefits of the Air Pollution Prevention and Control Actions in Heavily Polluted Regions
awd_abstract_narration:
The overall objective of this project is to examine the long-term health benefits of the 2013 "Air Pollution Prevention and Control Action Plan" in one of the most heavily polluted and populated regions in China: the Beijing-Tianjin-Hebei region. The project will be conducted at Tsinghua University under the mentorship of Dr. Shuxiao Wang, who is a noted expert in air pollution research. China is an ideal location to conduct air pollution research because of its available and abundant resources, as well as its political, scientific, and societal interests in the topic. This project will examine the health benefits, such as reduced cardiovascular outcome or premature deaths, of China's new comprehensive air pollution policy, which has resulted in reduced PM2.5 levels. Air pollution is a global environmental issue that is affecting both developed and developing countries, and has local air quality and also global climate impacts. Therefore, even though the research will be conducted in China, it will have impacts on the global community. Because China is one of the major emitters of air pollution, providing quantifiable information on: 1) existing pollution levels, 2) expected improvements in air quality from the new air pollution policy, and 3) estimated health benefits will enhance the global community's general and scientific understanding of this important issue. 

There are three input components to be used in the project. The first component, "Community Multi-scale Air Quality (CMAQ) output" , will have estimates of changes in ambient PM2.5 under the action plan. Second, demographic data will be collected from the National Bureau of Statistics of China. Lastly, "concentration-response functions (CRFs)" for premature death attributable to PM2.5 as well as other disease outcomes of interest will be derived from the epidemiological literature and expert syntheses of literature relevant to China. CRFs will represent the effect of changes in PM2.5 on health outcome incidence of interest. China's current circumstance - highly elevated PM2.5 concentrations, a large number of affected individuals, and rapidly changing pollution control measures - will offer some unique scenarios to investigate under the proposed project.

This award under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes Program supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Chinese Ministry of Science and Technology.

por.por_cntn:
This fellowship opportunity allowed me to expand my scientific knowledge and to be connected with researchers outside of the U.S. for future collaborations. I not only gained the technical skills necessary to conduct a health impact assessment, but also was able to further develop interpersonal skills to better communicate and work with people with different backgrounds and interests. In addition, some of the observations I made while in Beijing helped me develop some new research interests and also have a new perspective on how the air pollution issue should be approached.

The major goal of this project was to quantify the health benefits of the 2013 Air Pollution Prevention and Control Action Plan of China. This Action Plan included many details about how the government plans to tackle the issue of air pollution from multiple perspectives along with very specific goals to achieve short- and long-term in the "Jing-Jin-Ji" region (Beijing-Tianjin-Hebei) of China. This Action Plan tackles multiple air pollutants including PM2.5, which is known to be associated with an array of adverse health outcomes. The colleagues at Tsinghua already had developed simulated PM2.5 estimates under different air pollution reduction scenarios for year 2020. I used the PM2.5 estimates along with demographics, baseline mortality, and integrated exposure-function data to calculate the health benefits of the Action Plan.

The main research activities involved in my project were literature review, data manipulation and analysis, and visualization of the results. Literature review was done to better understand the health impact assessment process as well as to determine the best way to derive the concentration-response function between PM2.5 and mortalities from different health outcomes. Data manipulation and analysis were used to combine different datasets to calculate the number of avoidable premature deaths. The numbers of avoidable premature lung cancer deaths in the study region under the least, moderate and most reduction scenarios were 10900, 36800 and 51700 respectively. However, these numbers are likely to be larger if we consider those unregistered people that live in the region for work. In other words, the actualy health benefit of the air pollution policy is likely to be greater. 

In addition to gaining research and cultural experiences during the fellowship, some unique observations were made that was only possible because I was in China. I was able to better understand why some people take air pollution as a serious health risk that needs to be dealt with immediately while some others make other things, such as economic development, as a high priority after talking to many Chinese scholars and non-scholars. It also made me see the importance of developing, implementing, and spreading effective interventions to reduce personal exposure to air pollution in conjunction with conducting scientific research in order for our research to contribute to improving public health.
